Closed by #2000.
@csantanapr good idea - but is that a separate pr? as you point out there are many of these docs are dev only scatttered through out.

Looking at the [compose file](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-devtools/blob/master/docker-compose/docker-compose.yml) from the sidelines I notice the following:

The images are required to get a working service are:
 - image: couchdb:1.6
 - image: wurstmeister/zookeeper
 - image: wurstmeister/kafka
 - image: consul:v0.7.0
 - image: gliderlabs/registrator
 - image: whisk/controller:latest
 - image: whisk/invoker:latest
 - image: redis:2.8
 - image: adobeapiplatform/apigateway:1.1.0

I presume `whisk` would then be replaced by `openwhisk` however the [openwhisk docker repository](https://hub.docker.com/u/openwhisk)  holds no `invoker` nor 'controller` image.
It does however hold 2 api-gateway images (??) which are not referenced in the compose file.

Its also a bit remarkable that the setup uses both Zookeeper and Consul, but also both Kakfa and Redis. I can see how it got there (e.g. Kafka needs Zookeeper) but from a distance it looks like the setup can be optimized a bit and the repo can be cleaned up a bit ;-)

@rabbah close or anything else need it? ðŸ™ 
#1929 is merged now.

>Profile updated yes. But we need to automate the image push or build for our containers.

@rabbah I was just asking if when you said "profile" you were referring only to the the picture

@rabbah I see we have automated builds already for the runtimes.

Why we can't setup invoker and controller in the same way?

@seriousme 
>It does however hold 2 api-gateway images (??) which are not referenced in the compose file.

I clean up one of them there should be only one now `openwhisk/apigateway`

And docker compose file should be updated to use it https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-devtools/issues/2

The runtime builds are not automated - I occasionally click the build now button. That's of course not a long term answer. Either automated builds (pull model) or travis does the publishing (push model). I think all our components should have images on docker hub, that's the point of this issue, isn't it?
@csantanapr Invoker and Controller currently cannot be build automatically because we compile outside of the container. We can certainly change that but there might be sideeffects to consider.

>The runtime builds are not automated - I occasionally click the build now button. 

Why? I configured other images for pulling, I will enable automatic pulling then if there are no objections for the runtimes.

@rabbah I see errors in automatic builds for example `openwhisk/pythonaction`

Build failed: Error: image library/dockerskeleton:latest not found

Here https://hub.docker.com/r/openwhisk/pythonaction/builds/

It tried to build an hour ago

@markusthoemmes Would doing the compile with the docker build would have less side effects? then when the image is build/done the code is compiled and the image done, no window for errors if trying to compile in a different environment that can introduce side effects.
Isn't the easiest path through this to have travis do a travis push/tag at the end of a build from master?
As always thank you @jthomas

iâ€™m increasingly thinking the raw header mechanism to accept a raw body will not apply broadly to web actions: if one does not control the request, how does one add the required header? 

this makes this feature not very useful as a web action (absent an api gw or some proxy).
what if instead this was just another decorator on the the web action: 

```bash
wsk action create httpExample req.js --web-action --raw-http
```

>what if instead this was just another decorator on the the web action:

I'm fine with this option, I think it was on the table at one time during design discussions. 

Then one more less thing to configure on apigw to be concern ðŸ‘ðŸ¼

Just for the record, another option on the table was using an extension on the URI I.e. "default/action.raw"

But Iike the decorator if I have to choose, maybe have .raw as a secondary way
PG4 50 approved.

Hi Andy trying OpenWhisk on DigitalOcean?
Let us know how it goes and if we can improve the deployment instructions for Ubuntu. 

Your welcome to join our Slack if you have questions or want to share your experience http://slack.openwhisk.org
**Ready for review**: These are the remaining Python 3 syntax errors.  I tried to focus only on the errors to make this PR easy to review and approve.
Fixed in https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/2006
Closed in favor of https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/2007

@rabbah @mrutkows Thanks to the merging of recent PRs, `flake8` now finds no Python 3 syntax errors in this repo.  #1903 now adds a new `core/python2Action` with appropriate Dockerfile and build.gradle to allow us to continue to run Python 2 actions after the Python 3 upgrade.

Now that #2007 is merged, we have two choices:
1. Review and merge 1903 which would be minor a Python 2.7.12 to 2.7.13 (plus modules) upgrade that also creates the new `core/python2Action` --or--
2. Go the "big bang" approach and upgrade core/actionProxy and core/pythonAction to Python 3.

Thoughts?

- [ ] Modify wsk to accept --kind python:2 and --kind python:3
What is required to make that happen?
Can you clarify if X-OW-RAW-HTTP means the RAW json body posted?
Yes
Thanks - I'm 99% sure this is blocking me from using it for Alexa in production. What is the rough ETA?

You have access to the body today as input parameters 

Can you open an issue on what specific is your requirement?

Today you have access to the body as long is json and also all headers
Add any errors or sample code when you open the issue, also will serve as an use case for testing

This is related to #116 and is disabled intentionally. When @ioana-blue promoted sequences to first class actions, we kept the previous behavior (no parameters allowed) until we migrate all sequences that might exist in the db to the new schema. At which point we can enable this feature. 

Until then the work around is to create a package binding with parameters and sequence that instead.
Yeah if they require you to verify the body payload as a hash like a sha1 then it will not match
Cool. So any rough ETA?
It will be in GitHub Monday I'd expect.
Ok - another dumb question. :) If it is on GitHub Monday, when will it be available via Bluemix? (Ie, when can I use, blog it, etc. :)
Separate question - ask in internal slack.

This reminds me of this [conversation](https://lists.apache.org/thread.html/3c9b7b23283066449de42262ff3bbd61362fd99c3f6a9354ee0f1f76@%3Cdev.openwhisk.apache.org%3E) we had on the Apache DL when there was this idea that maybe OW shouldn't be so intrusive on the payload, but pass it "as-is" instead of decoding it. It looks like we got to that point; now I'm wondering if the plan is to still decode it and pass it twice: `raw` and `decoded`.

@cfjedimaster IIRC you also need the headers to check the signature. See - https://developer.amazon.com/public/solutions/alexa/alexa-skills-kit/docs/developing-an-alexa-skill-as-a-web-service#checking-the-signature-of-the-request . I don't recall reading that the Alexa SDK has support for this; I was actually thinking at implementing this in the Gateway for performance reasons.
FWiW, the Request object specified by PHP's Framework Interopability Group passes to body twice like this with raw available via `getBody()' and the decoded version via 'getParsedBody()'.
@ddragosd Yep, I know. The only part I have missing is the raw body.
@akrabat I'm not familiar with PHP but I'd like to verify an assumption that the body is not actually passed twice, but it's only decoded on-demand via `getParsedBody()` method ?
There are multiple libraries that implement the standard & so it depends on the implementation. It's more efficient to decode on first demand & cache the decoded result.

The raw-http indicator (originally suggested as a header, but now implemented as an annotation on the action) will pass the body as a base64 encoded string to the action (if binary content). To pass it as a raw byte stream requires further changes in the controller/invoker interface (which i posit are not in scope for this issue). This gets closer to making the payload more opaque.
PG4 59 approved.
Can you mix this in https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/tests/src/test/scala/whisk/core/entity/test/ExecHelpers.scala
Never mind I thought that was for a test. In the invoker and controller it is loaded at startup. You can get it from the singleton.
https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/common/scala/src/main/scala/whisk/core/entity/ExecManifest.scala

Without understanding all the implications (I hadn't realised how much work would be involved for 1.5% of Openwhisk code!) of going for the "Big Bang", it would seem to me preferable to upgrade `core/actionProxy` and `core/pythonAction` to Python 3.

**Need for a `--kind python:n` option?** Do we have any idea what impact this would have - i.e. can we quantify the number of applications' Openwhisk Containers in use that would require a `--kind python:n` option? i.e. be adversely impacted by things going over to Python 3

BTW it seems quite common for people to 

```
import asyncio 
import aiohttp 
import requests 
```

So if these libraries were available by default it would give a good range of functionality to applications deployed to an Openwhisk Container
Can we integrate this linter into our repository? Changing these files without bringing the necessary automation will just break after a while and get rotten.

I'm honestly unsure about this. Why is this needed? Is it the docker way to create so highly specialized images instead of having reusable pieces at hand to configure?

Also this isn't tested in anyway besides manually. We generally try to have tests for everything in this repository. Couldn't this be part of a seperate repository containing bits and pieces for different cloud providers?

I lint the OpenWhisk files by pulling them into a [separate repo with a Python oriented .travis.yml](https://github.com/cclauss/flake8_for_ow/blob/master/.travis.yml) file.  If someone can figure out how to do a Python test matrix inside a Scala oriented .travis.yml file, that would be cool.  Flake 8 changes behavior depending on which version of Python that it is running on so the Python 2 / Python 3 matrix is useful.  However if we could only get Python 3, that would be sufficient for our purposes.
@markusthoemmes this would be needed to ease the deployment in Mesos and Kube clusters.

The criteria for merging into the main repo is that new features are continuously tested. If they're not, they will rot. For example, the multicloud bits are surely rotted and broken - and I would like to move them to a different repo but have not gotten around to it. In the last week or so, we jettisoned several features, code, and the like because it's not tested, including the mobile starter app. And more is planned. 

So while I think there is consistent agreement that we should provide images for the container on dockerhub (issue https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/171), adding these builds steps for a deployment that is closer tied to the [developer tools repository](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-devtools/) suggests that is the better home for this change.

> Couldn't this be part of a seperate repository containing bits and pieces for different cloud providers?

@markusthoemmes we could; I'm not sure what's *cloud specific* in this couchdb image built reusing the ansible playbooks in this repo.

> adding these builds steps for a deployment that is closer tied to the developer tools repository suggests that is the better home for this change.

`docker-compose` flow in `openwhisk-devtools` repo it's currently building the images b/c #171 is not complete. The plan is to reuse those images from docker hub and skip the build. See: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-devtools/issues/3 
Then we'll need to find another home for building this container. 

To me it looked more natural to have it part of the main build which today builds all the other containers and also hosts the ansible scripts.

>  new features are continuously tested

good point. I wasn't sure how to integrate this so I left it off thinking we could have other flows (i.e. `travis` based) to do end-to-end testing including various deployments ( Ansible, Mesos, Kube, etc ).  I think for this container we could add a test showing that when it starts it initializes the Database as per the ansible config.

If regardless of the automated testing aspect we feel that architecturally it makes sense to keep it separate from this repo that builds all the other docker images, I'm happy to move down that path in order to make progress. We could have a special location on `openwhisk-devtools` repo, maybe a folder called `openwhisk-couchdb` and have this CouchDB docker image built there. We would also need to push it to Docker Hub from there as well. 

WDYT ?

> good point. I wasn't sure how to integrate this so I left it off thinking we could have other flows (i.e. travis based) to do end-to-end testing including various deployments ( Ansible, Mesos, Kube, etc ). I think for this container we could add a test showing that when it starts it initializes the Database as per the ansible config.

That's where I think we could have one repo per supported provider? I.e: The main repo is Ansible, as-is. We can have `openwhisk-kubernetes` which includes bits and pieces needed there. Each of the repos have their respective travis builds. If you ask me, that's the cleanest solution to the problem and it will make it far easier to advance in the smaller repos. Thoughts?

> If you ask me, that's the cleanest solution to the problem and it will make it far easier to advance in the smaller repos. 

ðŸ‘ ðŸ’¯  The common thing between `openwhisk-kubernetes`, `openwhisk-mesos-dcos`, `docker-compose`, etc are the docker images needed to be deployed. 

So if we feel we should build all containers but the couchDB one in this repo, then build `openwhisk-couchdb` as part of `openwhisk-devtools` I'm happy to go down this path as well.  Maybe in the future we'll build the other components in a standalone fashion, having the `controller` and `invoker` being built separately as well; looking from such an angle it makes sense to isolate the DB container given that it's not a *direct* dependency to the code, but to the deployment.

Yes you are absolutely right. We'd love to fan out all the repositories at one point, just haven't gotten to the point thus far.

Sounds like a good direction to take ðŸ‘

Note that the updated `openwhisk/swift3action`  includes `zip`, so no need for the `apt-get -qq install -y zip > /dev/null` line in `compile.sh`.

@starpit, the experimental route will remain intact for now. I'm assuming it will be removed at some point in the future, however.

PG4 65, approved.

Flake8 is [already in .travis.yml](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/.travis.yml#L35) ~but that runs under Python 2.7 so it will not find Python 3 syntax errors.  I could not figure out is how to install Python 3 before running flake8~.
rebased on master and squashed

~Upgrading .travis.yml to use **dist: trusty** will give us Python 3.5.2 which is good enough to run flake8.  https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/trusty-ci-environment~

Ready for review.
This fix is VERY important for Python 3 compatibility.  It allows us to pass 11 test cases that fail when we move from Python 2 to Python 3.
pg3/403 ðŸš€.

#1867 is VERY important for Python 3 compatibility. It allows us to pass 11 test cases that fail when we move from Python 2 to Python 3.  Now we have **just two failing tests** remaining...

**actionContainers.ActionProxyContainerTests > openwhisk/dockerskeleton [should run a python script](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/tests/src/test/scala/actionContainers/ActionProxyContainerTests.scala#L239) FAILED**
    org.scalatest.exceptions.TestFailedException: Some({}) was not equal to Some({"string":"hello"})

**actionContainers.ActionProxyContainerTests > openwhisk/dockerskeleton [should run a python script and confirm expected environment variables](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/tests/src/test/scala/actionContainers/ActionProxyContainerTests.scala#L239) FAILED**
